title: German submarine U-612
text:
German submarine "U-612" was a <a href="German%20Type%20VIIC%20submarine">Type VIIC</a> <a href="U-boat">U-boat</a> built for <a href="Nazi%20Germany">Nazi Germany</a>'s "<a href="Kriegsmarine">Kriegsmarine</a>" for service during <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>. She was ordered on 15 August 1940 and <a href="Keel%20laying">laid down</a> at <a href="Blohm%20%26amp%3B%20Voss">Blohm & Voss</a>, <a href="Hamburg">Hamburg</a>, on 21 April 1941. She was <a href="Ceremonial%20ship%20launching">launched</a> on 9 January 1942 and <a href="Ship%20commissioning">commissioned</a> 5 March 1942
"Oberleutnant zur See" Paul Siegmann was her first commanding officer. He was joined in May 1942 by <a href="Herbert%20Werner">Herbert Werner</a>, author of the book "<a href="Iron%20Coffins">Iron Coffins</a>", as First Officer.
While still on trials in the Baltic "U-612" was sunk in collision with on 6 August 1942. She was later salvaged and served as a training boat until the end of the war, when she was scuttled on 2 May 1945.
Design.
<a href="German%20Type%20VII%20submarine%23Type%20VIIC">German Type VIIC submarines</a> were preceded by the shorter <a href="German%20Type%20VII%20submarine%23Type%20VIIB">Type VIIB submarines</a>. "U-612" had a displacement of when at the surface and while submerged. She had a total length of , a <a href="pressure%20hull">pressure hull</a> length of , a <a href="beam%20%28nautical%29">beam</a> of , a height of , and a <a href="draught%20%28ship%29">draught</a> of . The submarine was powered by two <a href="Germaniawerft">Germaniawerft</a> F46 four-stroke, six-cylinder <a href="supercharged">supercharged</a> <a href="diesel%20engine">diesel engine</a>s producing a total of for use while surfaced, two <a href="Brown%2C%20Boveri%20%26amp%3B%20Cie">Brown, Boveri & Cie</a> GG UB 720/8 <a href="Motor%E2%80%93generator">double-acting electric motors</a> producing a total of for use while submerged. She had two shafts and two <a href="propeller">propeller</a>s. The boat was capable of operating at depths of up to .
The submarine had a maximum surface speed of and a maximum submerged speed of . When submerged, the boat could operate for at ; when surfaced, she could travel at . "U-612" was fitted with five <a href="torpedo%20tube">torpedo tube</a>s (four fitted at the bow and one at the stern), fourteen <a href="torpedo">torpedo</a>es, one <a href="8.8%20cm%20SK%20C/35%20naval%20gun">SK C/35 naval gun</a>, 220 rounds, and a <a href="2%20cm%20FlaK%2030">C/30</a> anti-aircraft gun. The boat had a <a href="Ship%27s%20company">complement</a> of between forty-four and sixty.
Service history.
After commissioning, "U-612" was engaged in working up and sea trials in the eastern <a href="Baltic%20Sea">Baltic</a>, assigned to <a href="5th%20U-boat%20Flotilla">5th U-boat Flotilla</a> and based at <a href="K%C3%B6nigsberg">Königsberg</a>. 
On 6 August 1942 she was at sea off <a href="Danzig">Danzig</a> when she was accidentally rammed by "U-444". Werner describes the event in his book; he states neither boat was aware of the other and that the captain of "U-444" was unaware he had struck "U-612". He describes in detail the struggle to get out of the rapidly sinking U-boat, and the crew's rescue by two other U-boats, one of which he states was the hapless "U-444" Two men died in the incident.
Siegman and his crew undertook to salvage "U-612" and put her back into action; the hull was raised during August but found to be too water-damaged for them to continue. The U-boat was handed over to the dockyard at Danzig and Seigmann and his crew were reassigned to another boat, .
"U-612" completed repairs the following year and was re-commissioned 31 May 1943. However she was deemed unsuitable as a "Front-boat" and was confined to training in the Baltic. 
On commissioning, under Oblt. T Petersen she joined <a href="24th%20U-boat%20Flotilla">24 Flotilla</a>, a training unit. In February 1944 she joined <a href="31st%20U-boat%20Flotilla">31 Flotilla</a>, another training unit, under the command of "Oblt.z.S." HP Dick.
On 2 May 1945 she was caught at <a href="Warnemunde">Warnemunde</a> by the advancing Red Army and was scuttled to avoid seizure.
